items.content:
This unit is about angles. Angles play an important role in constructions like bridges, cranes and roller coasters, but also in patterns in tiles in a stained-glass window.

At the end of this theme you will design a stained-glass window yourself, but first you will learn what kind of angles exist and how you can measure, draw and calculate angles.

prompt.body:
Stap 1: TDraw a triangle in your notebook and make sure that all sides are longer than your pencil.

Stap 2: Place your pencil on one side of the triangle with the point in one corner. This is how you start.

Stap 3: Turn your pencil along the first corner to the next side.

Stap 4: Slide your pencil along this side to the next corner.

Stap 5: Turn your pencil along the second corner.

Step 3-5

Stap 6: Slide your pencil along this side to the next corner.

Stap 7: Turn your pencil along the third corner.

Stap 8: Slide your pencil along this side to the next corner. (this is the corner where you started).

Step 6-8

Question: What happened to the direction of the pencil?

values.value: The pencil made a half turn. The pencil points in the opposite direction.

content.body: The pencil made a half turn. The pencil points in the opposite direction.

prompt.body:
Draw a large quadrilateral and do the pencil turning trick.

  1. What happened to the direction of the pencil?
  2. What do you think that happens to the direction of the pencil when you do the trick on a pentagon? Or on a hexagon?
  3. What can you tell about the direction of the pencil at a polygon in general?

values.value:
1. The direction of the pencil is the same as at the beginning. The pencil made a full turn.
  2. The pencil points to the opposite direction on a pentagon (one and a half turn) and in the same direction on a hexagon (two full turns).
  3. On a polygon with an odd number of angles the pencil turns in the opposite direction and on a polygon with an even number of angles in the same direction as in the beginning.

content.body:
1. The direction of the pencil is the same as at the beginning. The pencil made a full turn.
  2. The pencil points to the opposite direction on a pentagon (one and a half turn) and in the same direction on a hexagon (two full turns).
  3. On a polygon with an odd number of angles the pencil turns in the opposite direction and on a polygon with an even number of angles in the same direction as in the beginning.

prompt.body:
In the picture below, the skateboarder does the "Ollie 180" (from right to left)

Look at the picture.

  1. How can you see that the skateboarder made a half turn?
  2. Can you think of a name for a similar trick where the skateboarder makes a full turn?

Professional skateboarders sometimes do tricks where they turn 1080 'degrees'.

  1. How many full turns does a skateboarder make when he does a 1080 degrees trick?
  2. Suppose that 180 degrees is the smallest turn and 1080 degrees the biggest turn that a skateboarder can make. What are the jumps can a skateboarder make where he lands either left foot or right foot in front.

values.value:
1. Before the trick he had his right foot in front and after the trick his left foot in front.
  2. How about Ollie 360
  3. Three full turns
  4. 180, 360, 540, 720, 900, 1080

content.body:
1. Before the trick he had his right foot in front and after the trick his left foot in front.
  2. How about Ollie 360
  3. Three full turns
  4. 180, 360, 540, 720, 900, 1080

items.content:
In this introduction you have seen that a half turn is an angle of 180 degrees and a full turn is an angle of 360 degrees.

Since you can not draw an angle greater than 360 degrees, we will only use angles between 0 and 360 degrees in this unit.

In this unit you will learn to:

  • recognize and name different types of angles
  • recognize and name different types of triangles
  • to measure the size of all kinds of angles with a protractor
  • to draw all kinds of angles and figures with angles with a protractor
  • calculate angles in triangles, quadrilaterals and other polygons
  • calculate angles by using parallel and intersecting lines

You already do know what a triangle is.

In the following exercises you will look at the angles of a triangle. What is so special about them?

prompt.body:
Of course every traingle has three angles. In this example these angles are numbered: , en . You will find four copies of this triangle on the cutting sheet.

  1. Cut the four triangles Knip de vier exemplaren uit and use them to lay a larger triangle. Stick it in your notebook.

The large triangle also has three angles.

  1. Compare the angles of the large triangle and the angles of the small triangles. Are they equal?

The three small triangles come together halfway along the sides of the large triangle.

  1. What are the numbers of the angles that meet there?
  2. The same questions (a, b, c) for the next triangle.

values.value:
2. The angles of the large triangle are equal to the angles of teh small traingles: \(1\), \(2\) and \(3\).
  3. Halfway along the sides pf the large triangle the angles with numbers \(1\), \(2\) and \(3\) come together.
  4. The same answers as with b. and c.

content.body:
2. The angles of the large triangle are equal to the angles of teh small traingles: , and .
  3. Halfway along the sides pf the large triangle the angles with numbers , and come together.
  4. The same answers as with b. and c.

prompt.body:
In the drawing we added rectangles of 1 cm width on the sides of the first triangle of the previous question. These rectangles are connected by circular arcs with radius 1 cm.

  1. How big are the three ocher-colored pieces of circle together?
  2. Draw a triangle that looks like the second triangle of the previous question.
    Draw rectangles with width 1 cm on the sides of the triangle.
    Connect the rectangles with arcs.
    How big are the three arc segments together?

values.value:
1. Together the three ocher-colored pieces are a full circle.


  2. Together the three arc segments are a full circle.

content.body:
1. Together the three ocher-colored pieces are a full circle.


  2. Together the three arc segments are a full circle.

items.content: The unit 'Angles and shapes' consists of the following parts:

A Super variant is available for a number of exercises in this section.
That Super variant is a bit more difficult.
Note: When you do the 'Super' exercise, you do not have to make the 'normal' exercise.
You recognize the tasks that are a Super variant by this sign
Als je op dit teken klikt, dan ga je naar de Super variant.


You will see this sign is in the Super variant

If you click on it, it will take you back to the normal exercise.

Note: the Super assignments are also grouped always together at the bottom of each section.

In this unit we will work on angles and shapes.
Angles play an important role in constructions like bridges, cranes and roller coasters, but also in patterns in tiles in a stained-glass window.

In the following sections you will learn what kind of angles there are and how you can measure, draw and calculate angles.

Section 1 Turning around
Section 2 Measuring angles
Section 3 Special triangles
Section 4 The sum of angles of a triangle
Section 5 Working with the sum of angles
Section 6 The sum of angles of a polygon

degrees

A full rotation is .

types of angles

A right angle is .
An acute angles is less than .
A straight angle is .
An obtuse angle is greater than and less than .
A reflex angle is greater than .

labeling and notation

This angle is called angle .

The corner point of an angle is called the vertex and the two straight sides are called arms.
The angle is the amount of turn between each arm.
In triangle i, is a side and is an angle.
In this example is mm, .

isoscales triangle

An isoscales triangle has two equal sides. The thrird side is the base; the apex is the vertex where the two sides of equal length meet, opposite the base.

Key point
In an isoscales traingle the angles opposite the sides of equal length are equal. They other way around: when two angles in a traingle are equal, it is an isoscales triangle.
this is the way to draw a right angle

types of triangles

An equilateral Triangle has three equal sides and 3 equal angles of 60º.

An acute triangle has three angles of less than 90º.

A right triangle has one right angle.

An obtuse triangle has one angle of more than 90º.

equal angles

Vertically opposite angles are equal.
When 2 parallel lines get crossed by another line (which is called a Transversal), you can see that corresponding angles (F-angles) and alternate angles (Z-angles) are the same.

sum of angles

The sum of angles of a triangle is .
The sum of angles of a polygon with angles is .

You are going to design a stained-glass window with a geometric, islamic pattern

Unit assignment Angles and shapes

You will now do a test in which you can show that you have mastered the material learned from the previous sections.

You will pass the test if you get a score of 70%.

prompt.body:
a) How large is the sum of the angles of pentagon ABCDE?
HERE you can download a document with the pentagon;
print the document to be able to measure and draw precisely.

b) The sum of angles of another polygon is 5400 °.
How many angles does this polygon have?

c) Color in pentagon ABCDE the acute angles red, the obtuse angles blue
and the reflex angles green.

d) Measure each of the angles of the pentagon and write down the result at each of the corners.

values.value:
a) The sum of angles is (5 - 2) ∙ 180 ° = 540 °.

b) 5400 °: 180 ° = 30, so you can divide the polygon into 30 triangles.
The polygon therefore has 30 + 2 = 32 angles

c, d) You may deviate a degree in the measurement of angles, but the angular sum must be correct!

content.body:
a) The sum of angles is (5 - 2) ∙ 180 ° = 540 °.

b) 5400 °: 180 ° = 30, so you can divide the polygon into 30 triangles.
The polygon therefore has 30 + 2 = 32 angles

c, d) You may deviate a degree in the measurement of angles, but the angular sum must be correct!

prompt.body:
A regular pentagon ABCDE is drawn below. The circle on which the angles lie has center M. The sides of the pentagon are 3 cm long.

a) Calculate the following angles:

∠EMD, ∠AMC, ∠CAM.

b) The regular pentagon is the base of a regular five-sided pyramid T⋅ABCDE.
All ribs of the pyramid are 3 cm long.

Which special triangle is triangle TAB?
And triangle TMC? And triangle ACT?

c) Draw a triangle on your work-out sheet in which you can measure the actual size of angle ACT. State clearly how you have drawn the triangle.

d) Measure in your drawing how large angle ACT is and write the result in that angle.

values.value:
a) ∠EMD = 360 °: 5 = 72 ° ∠AMC = 2 × 72 ° = 144 ° ∠CAM = (180 ° - 144 °): 2 = 18 °

b) Triangle TAB is equilateral
Triangle TMC is rectangular
Triangle ACT is isosceles

c,d)

content.body:
a) ∠EMD = 360 °: 5 = 72 ° ∠AMC = 2 × 72 ° = 144 ° ∠CAM = (180 ° - 144 °): 2 = 18 °

b) Triangle TAB is equilateral
Triangle TMC is rectangular
Triangle ACT is isosceles

c,d)

prompt.body:
From triangle ABC, we know that angle C is straight. Furthermore: ∠A = 2⋅∠B.
a) Work out the angles of triangle ABC?

b) From triangle PQR, we know that angle Q is 12° greater than angle P.
Angle R is twice as large as angle Q.
Work out the angles of triangle PQR?

values.value:
a) ∠A + ∠B = 180 ° - 90 ° = 90 °. ∠B is 1/3 of 90 ° = 30 ° and ∠A is 2/3 part of 90 ° = 60 °.

b) See picture:

4 asterisks + 36° = 180°, so 4 asterisks = 144°, so 1 asterisk = 36°. So ∠P = 36°, ∠Q = 36° + 12° = 48°, ∠R = 2 · 48° = 96°.

content.body:
a) ∠A + ∠B = 180 ° - 90 ° = 90 °. ∠B is 1/3 of 90 ° = 30 ° and ∠A is 2/3 part of 90 ° = 60 °.

b) See picture:

4 asterisks + 36° = 180°, so 4 asterisks = 144°, so 1 asterisk = 36°. So ∠P = 36°, ∠Q = 36° + 12° = 48°, ∠R = 2 · 48° = 96°.

prompt.body:
Below is the map of an island.
1 cm on the map is in reality 350 m.

The map can also be downloaded HERE for printing so that you can draw on it.

a) What is the scale of the map?

b) In the bay of the island there is a boat A. Because the island is overgrown, you can't look from one side to the other.
Color the part of the sea that you can see from the middle of boat A (that is the dot).

c) There is a scuplture on the island. From this sculpture, ship B can be seen exactly in a south-easterly direction and boat A in a north-easterly direction.
Determine the location of the sculpture on the map.

d) Ship B sails on a straight course from west to east.
Indicate with a cross the place where ship B is, when it can be seen from boat A in the bay for the first time.

e) The ship will travel 450 meters per minute. It still has to cover 330 meters to get to the cross.
How long does it take before ship B can be seen from boat A?

f) Below you see a map of the sculpture. This map is made up of squares (1), rhombuses (2) and arrowheads (3).
Calculate the size of the angles a, b, c, d and e.

values.value:
a) 350 m = 35.000 cm, thus scale 1 : 35.000

b,c,d)

e) That is the \({330 \over 450} = {33 \over 45} = {11 \over 15} = {44 \over 60}\)part of a minute, so 44 sec

f)

∠a = 360° : 6 = 60°

∠b = (360° – ∠a – ∠a) : 2 = (360° – 60° – 60°) : 2 = 240° : 2 = 120°

or ∠b = 180° – ∠a = 180° – 60° = 120°      
   
∠c = (360° – 90° – 2·∠b) : 2 = (270° – 2∙120°) : 2 = 30° : 2 = 15°

∠d = 360° –  ∠a = 360° – 60° = 300°

∠e = 360° – 2·∠c – ∠d  = 360° – 2·15° – 300°  = 30°

content.body:
a) 350 m = 35.000 cm, thus scale 1 : 35.000

b,c,d)

e) That is the part of a minute, so 44 sec

f)

∠a = 360° : 6 = 60°

∠b = (360° - ∠a - ∠a) : 2 = (360° - 60° - 60°) : 2 = 240° : 2 = 120°

or ∠b = 180° - ∠a = 180° - 60° = 120°

∠c = (360° - 90° - 2·∠b) : 2 = (270° - 2∙120°) : 2 = 30° : 2 = 15°

∠d = 360° - ∠a = 360° - 60° = 300°

∠e = 360° - 2·∠c - ∠d = 360° - 2·15° - 300° = 30°

prompt.body:
From triangle PQR we know that PQ = 7 cm, ∠P = 37° and ∠R = 95°.
Draw triangle PQR accurately.
Put the letters and the number of degrees in each angle.
Write down step by step how you have drawn triangle PQR.

values.value:
1. Draw PQ with a length of 7 cm.
2. Draw ∠P = 37 °.
3. Calculate ∠Q. ∠Q = 180 ° - 37 ° - 95 ° = 48 °.
4. Draw ∠Q = 48 °.
5. The intersection of the two lines is point R.

content.body:
1. Draw PQ with a length of 7 cm.
2. Draw ∠P = 37 °.
3. Calculate ∠Q. ∠Q = 180 ° - 37 ° - 95 ° = 48 °.
4. Draw ∠Q = 48 °.
5. The intersection of the two lines is point R.

items.content:
There are 2 additional exercises. You only need to do one.

  • Strengthen is intended for learners that failed the unit test.
  • Extend is intended for learners that passed the unit test.

So, please first take the unit test before you do teh addotional exercises.
Ask your teacher if you don't know which additional exercise you should do.

prompt.body:
Bill is on a train. He sees the sun in the middle of the window. Suddenly he sees the sun change location. Then he sees the sun go back to his old place.

What happened? Explain this with a sketch of (the top view of) the railway.

values.value: The train has made a left turn (if Bill looks in the direction of travel) and then an equally large right turn:

content.body: The train has made a left turn (if Bill looks in the direction of travel) and then an equally large right turn:

prompt.body:
We are standing right in front of a drain pipe. We see picture 1. The inside of the pipe is dark and behind it we see the sky: that is the light circle. There are four more picture: 2, 3, 4 and 5.

  1. Which picture do we see when we move towards the pipe, or ?
  2. Which picture do we see when we move to the right, or ?

Suppose the drain pipe is meter long and has a diameter of meter. Your eye is in front of the center of the pipe. View the sketch of a side view of the situation.

  1. Make an accurate drawing to scale.

The angle at which you see the front is indicated by a curve in the sketch..

  1. Measure that angle.
  2. Also measure the angle at which you see the back of the drain pipe.

values.value:
1. \(2\)
  2. \(4\)

  4. \(28°\)
  5. \(8°\)

prompt.body:
In the middle of the picture you see an equilateral triangle. Furthermore, the shape consists of rectangles and isosceles triangles.

  1. Calculate the angles , , en .

The whole shape is a hexagon.

  1. Work out each of the angles of the hexagon?
  2. Draw a regular hexagon with sides of cm.
  3. Divide the hexagon in the same way into a regular triangle, three rectangles and three isosceles triangles.

    \(∠b=360°−60°−2⋅90°=120°\)
    \(∠c=∠d=(180°−120°):2=30°\)

  4. See above.

prompt.body:
This shape consists of four different types of rhombuses. It is also available on your worksheet .

Calculate the angles of each of the rhombuses.
Write down your calculations.

values.value:
See the picture for the letters. Calculate consecutively:
\(∠a=360°:9=40°\)
\(∠b=180°−40°=140°\)
\(∠c=360°−2⋅140°=80°\)
\(∠d=180°−80°=100°\)
\(∠e=360°−40°−2⋅100°=120°\)
\(∠f=180°−120°=60°\)
\(∠g=360°−80°−2⋅60°=160°\)
\(∠h=180°−160°=20°\)

prompt.body:
Lighthouses contain a rotating lamp system. Each lighthouse uses its lights for a unique signal.
As an example we look at a signal from a lighthouse that consists of two short flashes and one long flash. See the picture below. The largest "white" angle of belongs to the long flash. he light system of this lighthouse revolves once in seconds. You can download the picture HERE.

  1. How many seconds is the long flash visible from a point at sea? Write down your calculation.
  2. Measure the angle corresponding to the time between two short flashes. How long is the time between two short flashes? Write down your calculation.

values.value:
1. \( 36:360=0,1 \); \(0,1⋅30=3\) seconds.
  2. That angle is \(120°\).
    \(120:360= \frac13\); \(\frac13⋅30=10\) seconds.

content.body:
1. ; seconds.
  2. That angle is .
    ; seconds.

colophon.title: Over dit lesmateriaal
colophon.description:
Het thema 'Procenten' is ontwikkeld door auteurs en medewerkers van StudioVO.

Fair Use
In de Stercollecties van StudioVO wordt gebruik gemaakt van beeld- en filmmateriaal dat beschikbaar is op internet. Bij het gebruik zijn we uitgegaan van fair use. Meer informatie: Fair use

Mocht u vragen/opmerkingen hebben, neem dan contact op via de helpdesk VO-content.
